title: The Prandtl Number
subtitle: Conductive vs. Convective Heat Transfer
about:
Both conduction and convection happen in fluids. As heat transfer
through both processes reduces the temperature difference, they can be
considered as competing against each other in transferring heat. There
are many different types of fluids, such as air, water, oil, or mercury.
The rates of conduction and convection vary in different fluids.
Sometimes, conduction dominates. Other times, convection dominates. The
Prandtl number is a parameter that can be used to roughly determine
which process will \"win\":

Pr=ν/α
{: .formula}

where *ν* is the kinematic viscosity and *α* is the thermal diffusivity.
If a fluid is more viscous (sticky), the Prandtl number is greater and
the heat transfer will be more conductive.

The following simulation shows how fluids with different Prandtl numbers
transfer heat.
